title-group.article-title: Coronary Lesions Complexity in Patients With Stable Coronary Artery Disease

body.p: We read the article “Predictors of Coronary Lesions Complexity in Patients With Stable Coronary Artery Disease” by Aksakal et al with interest. 1 They investigated the independent clinical predictors of SYNTAX score (SS) in 436 consecutive patients with stable angina pectoris, who underwent coronary angiography. They demonstrated the complexity of coronary heart diseases (CHDs) assessed by SS. Presence of diabetes mellitus (DM), no previous statin use, and lower values of high-density lipoprotein cholesterol, left ventricular ejection fraction, and estimated glomerular filtration rate were independent predictors of CHD complexity.

Red blood cell distribution width (RDW), an inexpensive and easily measurable laboratory variable, may also predict CHD complexity. Akın et al 2 evaluated the relationship between RDW and severity of CHD in patients with acute myocardial infarction. They analyzed the relation between RDW and angiographic severity of CAD. Patients with elevated SSs (>32) had higher RDW values. The SS was positively correlated with RDW. 2

The ankle-brachial index (ABI) is a useful diagnostic tool for peripheral arterial disease (PAD). The ABI may also predict cardiovascular prognosis in diabetic patients with complications. 3 Measurement of ABI in patients with subclinical PAD allows the timely initiation of preventive measures as well as the recognition of vascular disease in other arterial beds. When the ABI is either <0.9 or >1.3, PAD is predicted to be present. 4 Aggressive vascular risk factor modification in patients with PAD is associated with a reduction in the risk of vascular events as well as decreased disease progression. 5,6 Both RDW and ABI are rapid, reliable, low-cost, and noninvasive tests; several other markers/tests such as C-reactive protein may reflect the complexity of CHD. For this reason, the study would be stronger if Aksakal et al measured these markers and carried out a correlation analysis between ABI and RDW with these markers in their study. 1

Cardiovascular risk factors (eg, DM, hypercholesterolemia, arterial hypertension, smoking, and overweight) may affect the ABI. 7 It would be useful, if the authors provided data about these risk factors and their possible relationship with the ABI and RDW. We believe that these findings will provide useful information about the relationship between ABI and RDW and predicting the complexity of CHD.
